utterances: Not everyone certainly will have a chance to make their way to the Franklin Institute.
I want you to quickly walk me through and describe a few of the mummies that visitors encounter.
Baron von Holtz.
He was buried with his boots on, and you can see his fingers, his toes, his teeth; very intricate details of him, as well as his 17th-century boots.
And there's the South American child found in Peru many, many years before King Tut was entombed.
Tell me about that child.
And instead of taking it out and analyzing it, they took the computer files and created what is known as a stereolithography.
They took the computer files and created a - almost a replica of this amulet and it's displayed with it.
So some of the secrets are still hidden within, but we're able to pull out as well.
James Delay, it's been a pleasure to speak to you.
Thank you very much.
Thank you very much.
This has been an honor.

James Delay is the director of exhibition development with American Exhibitions Incorporated, that's the firm that's running the ""Mummies of the World Exhibit"" at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia.

We're back with ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Guy Raz.
Always try to teach today as the only day that matters.
I try to get that across to forget the past.

The words of John Wooden from a 2004 interview on NPR.
The legendary coach of the UCLA men's basketball team died last night at the age of 99.
And from Southern California this week, we're joined by Conor Friedersdorf for a look at the ideas behind the headlines.
He writes about urban affairs and politics for theatlantic.com.
His blog is called the Urban Scene.
Conor, welcome back.
Thank you.
I've seen photos, Conor, of vigils on the UCLA campus already for John Wooden.
I was curious about something you wrote this week on the blog and it was called ""What Unites Los Angeles.
Yes.
And the answer is the Los Angeles Lakers.
Yes, of course.
And basketball fans actually in Los Angeles, over the last couple of generations, have been very lucky.
Of course, with John Wooden dying this week, there's been a lot of memories of the 10 titles that he won at UCLA.
And, of course, he was coaching and winning in an era when the Dodgers had Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale and the Lakers had Wilt Chamberlain and Jerry West and Elgin Baylor.
That was just a tremendous time to be alive and watching sports in Los Angeles.
And now with the Lakers winning championships again and playing now against the hated Celtics...
Very hated Celtics.
Yes.
And it's an interesting contrast because Coach Wooden, he liked the old school college-style basketball, teamwork and hated showiness.
And even back in the days of Jerry West and Elgin Baylor, he didn't want his players watching the Lakers because he thought that they would learn bad habits.
So we can only imagine what he thought of the Showtime Lakers in the '80s when Magic Johnson was doing no-look passes.
But Los Angeles has encompassed both the John Wooden style of college basketball and the Lakers Showtime style of basketball that residents have loved over the years.
Conor, moving into completely different direction.

Two Republican women are hoping to win the nomination for governor and senator in your state, in California, obviously Meg Whitman and Carly Fiorina, respectively, two former CEOs in the tech industry.
It seems like both of these candidates are pushing their moderate credentials unlike Republican candidates in primaries elsewhere.
Is that what California Republicans are looking for?
I want to make sure everybody understands we're sitting here saying we dodged a bullet.
Compared to Ivan, we dodged a bullet.
We still had a hurricane.
The Escambia County Sheriffs Department in Pensacola let relatives of department employees use the building as a storm shelter.
Yesterday evening, just a few hours after Dennis made landfall, people streamed from the shelter into the parking lot carrying their sleeping bags and pillows.
An outdoor generator kept power going inside.
(Soundbite of generator)
Helen White(ph) rode out the storm with her grandkids at the sheriffs department.
Last year, Hurricane Ivan crumbled her mobile home.
I said after Ivan I would never stay in town for the next one, but I'm here still.
She bought a new home after Ivan.
Dennis spared it.
I'm about to go back home, and all I have now is no electricity.
I still have my house, but I have no electricity.
But that'll be fine.
That'll be on in a few days, if not tomorrow.
With sustained winds of 120 miles an hour, Dennis did cause damage.
Across the sheriffs department parking lot, the wind ripped some metal sheeting off of the walls of a gas station.
One piece dangled like a loose tooth as the last gust of the storm passed through.
(Soundbite of metal sheeting)
Grover Barns(ph) is the sheriffs department mechanic who rode out the storm with a group of men in a nearby garage.
When them garage doors were moving in and out as the gusts were coming, it looked like they were going to come in the building with us.
We were somewhat apprehensive.
As a matter of fact, we was scared.
As Barns talks, Sheriffs Department Sergeant Ted Roy pulls his car into the garage to get a tire changed.
(Soundbite of electric tool)
He's just come back from Pensacola Beach which is still closed to the public.
He says the scale of emergency response to this hurricane does not even compare with that of Ivan.
For example, the first priority after Ivan was search and rescue.
We had over 700 or 900 calls--I can't remember which one it was--waiting to be answered and a lot of them were, `Come save me.
There's water in my house.
Please help me,' when we had to say, `We can't, we can't make it yet.
This time, we didn't have any of those calls waiting.
Roy says the main priority this time is cleanup.
Power crews and dump trucks are hitting the road this morning.
Ari Shapiro, NPR News.
A National Book Award is nice, but publishers want even more to be able to promote a book as a national best-seller.
So there has been a proliferation of best-seller lists.
And each is just a little bit different.
Recently, The New York Times made a change that will add even more books to its list.
NPR's Lynn Neary reports on what it means to be a best-seller.

In a move that will make more authors and their publishers happy, The New York Times divided its paperback best-seller list into two: a list for mass market paperbacks, usually dominated by genre fiction like romance novels and thrillers, and another for trade paperbacks that tend to be works of literary fiction.
Sam Tanenhaus, editor of the Sunday Times Book Review section, says The Times wanted to make more room for the kind of book their subscribers like to read.
He says they started thinking about making some changes a few years ago, when they noticed that Jeffrey Eugenides' ""Middlesex"" was raking in sales.
Hundreds of thousands had been sold, well over half a million.

It had not once appeared on our best-seller list, whereas other titles that one couldn't even remember because they would bob up to the surface of the list for a week, disappear, sink, and be replaced by another one worth hogging the list.
Getting on the New York Time's best-seller list is a much sought-after goal in the publishing world.
But the publishers don't like what they see there.
They can always turn to USA Today or regional newspapers or magazines or Amazon.com or any one of a number of other lists that can legitimately bestow the title best-seller on a book.
Boy, it can mean anything, can't it?
Terry Adams is vice president and director of trade paperbacks at Little Brown and Company.
He says there is no magic number that makes a book a best-seller.
I was just looking at the BookScan list today and there was a book that sold, let's say, 125,000 copies in one week, and it was the number one non-fiction best-seller.
Well, the next week, the number one non-fiction best-seller had sold 30-odd thousand copies.
Nielsen BookScan is another way that publishers can find out how their books are doing.
About sixty-five retail locations report their actual sales on a weekly basis.
And publishers pay to get that information.
Publishers can also consult BookSense, the bestseller list based on reports from independent bookstores.
